I don't feel like I learned much at all from this class. Discussions were too theoretical and high-level, did not provide me with deeper understanding of health policy or enable me to better work as a health policy professional. The one assignment that I found helpful was the morality paper, but even that did not feel very practical / realistic, as creating morality-based policy briefs does not apply really to the real world. 

The class would function better if the capstone assignment were started earlier and made more of a prominent focus of the class, with additional drafts due throughout the semester so students could get feedback and then revise their policy suggestions, in order to create a final product that we are proud of. 

Also, I'd solicit additional student feedback about what actual material would be helpful to include in a capstone and focus on allowing them to discuss this / learn about this, instead of Prof Schlesinger just providing all of the ideas.

Prof. Schlesinger's lecture / teaching style does not work for me. He clearly has a strong sense of where the lecture needs to go, to the point that any student contribution that is not explicitly in alignment with his idea of the "right answer." This creates a dynamic where students work to guess what he wants them to say, instead of saying their true opinions on the topics. This class would work MUCH better as a true seminar, where the professor speaks less than 20% of the time and health policy students are tasked with discussing readings and learning from one another. This style would encourage more creative thinking and critical analysis.

Also, Prof Schlesinger spoke about the obesity epidemic in a way I found offensive. We spent 3 classes discussing this topic and after each I left upset and frustrated. Using terms like "fat people" and being intentionally provocative in his rhetoric regarding personal responsibility & how people are to blame for their own weight was insensitive. For students in the class with a history of eating disorders, any conversations about weight can be upsetting or triggering, and I thought the way we discussed obesity was incredibly inappropriate. I'd prefer completely removing this topic from the syllabus, or drastically reformatting it in order to avoid the moralization of obesity.
